fields.yaml: {0: {'score': '1', 'isdefault': False, 'mapped_score': '1', 'label': 'Nothing'}, 1: {'score': '2', 'isdefault': False, 'mapped_score': '2', 'label': 'Lose or gain weight'}, 2: {'score': '3', 'isdefault': False, 'mapped_score': '3', 'label': 'Eat healthy food'}, 3: {'score': '4', 'isdefault': False, 'mapped_score': '4', 'label': 'Eat several small meals per day "(e.g., 6 small meals per day instead of 3 large ones)'}}

fields.yaml: {0: {'score': '0', 'isdefault': False, 'mapped_score': '0', 'label': 'Yes and I know what to do'}, 1: {'score': '1', 'isdefault': False, 'mapped_score': '1', 'label': 'Yes but I am unsure what to do'}, 2: {'score': '2', 'isdefault': False, 'mapped_score': '2', 'label': 'Yes but I am unable to do it'}, 3: {'score': '3', 'isdefault': False, 'mapped_score': '3', 'label': 'No'}}

fields.yaml: {0: {'score': '0', 'isdefault': False, 'mapped_score': '0', 'label': 'I understand everything I need to know'}, 1: {'score': '1', 'isdefault': False, 'mapped_score': '1', 'label': 'I understand what I have been told but I would like to know more'}, 2: {'score': '2', 'isdefault': False, 'mapped_score': '2', 'label': 'I am slightly confused about my medicines'}, 3: {'score': '3', 'isdefault': False, 'mapped_score': '3', 'label': 'I am very confused about my medicines'}}

fields.success_message: Thanks for taking part in this study. Your help is greatly appreciated.

fields.name: Conseqences of asthma
fields.success_message: Thanks for taking part in this study. Your help is greatly appreciated.

fields.label: I have been told what to do and the doctor/nurse has given me written instructions
Yes and I know what to do
Now that my disease is being treated, I will probably get better
I have been told what to do and the doctor/nurse has given me written instructions
I push myself as much as I can
I understand everything I need to know
Used to smoke but don't now  (skip the next 2 questions)
Yes but I am unsure what to do
Now that my disease is being treated, I will probably stay the same
I understand what I have been told but I would like to know more
I have been told but it is not written on paper
I have been told but it isn't written on paper
I haven't been told but I know what to do
I am slightly confused about my medicines
I haven't been told but I know what to do
Yes but I am unable to do it
I haven't been told and I don’t know what to do
Eat several small meals per day "(e.g., 6 small meals per day instead of 3 large ones)
I am very confused about my medicines
I haven't been told and I am uncertain when an ambulance should be called
Yes, it will change my life
I am prepared to give it a go
I will do anything it takes
Yes, it is something I look forward to
Not troubled by breathlessness except on strenuous exercise
Short of breath when hurrying or walking up a slight hill
Walks slower than contemporaries on level ground because of breathlessness, or has to stop for breath when walking at own pace
Stops for breath after walking about 100 metres or after a few minutes on level ground
Too breathless to leave the house, or breathless when dressing or undressing

fields.text: A likert type question
A list of radio buttons
A pulldown menu
A short-text answer
A large text box for which an answer is required.

# Instructions here

We can use any markdown syntax we like, e.g.

- Lists of items

1. And ordered lists
2. Of other things

Or **bold**, *italic* etc.
This question requires an integer answer (and won't accept letters)
Checkboxes useful sometimes!
Do you like cheese? Press 1 for yes. Zero for no.
Thanks. Goodbye.
You said {{score}}
Would you like us to demonstrate Signalbox by sending an email, an SMS message, and calling the mobile telephone number you provided?
In the **past 4 weeks**, how much of the time did your asthma keep you from getting as much done at work, school or at home?
During the **past 4 weeks**, how often have you had shortness of breath?
During the **past 4 weeks**, how often did your asthma symptoms (wheezing, coughing, shortness of breath, chest tightness or pain) wake you up at night or earlier than usual in the morning?
During the **past 4 weeks**, how often have you used your reliever inhaler (usually blue)?
How would you rate your asthma control during the past 4 weeks?
In the last month have you experienced any of the following?
Edit your new question
Please capture an image of your whole face.
How bad was the **Heartburn**?
How bad was the **Constipation**?
How bad was the **Diarrhoea **?
How bad was the **Back pain**?
How bad was the **Painful joints**?
How bad was the **Feeling tired for no reason**?
How bad was the **Headache or migraine**?
Little interest or pleasure in doing things?
Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless?
Trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much?
Feeling tired or having little energy?
Poor appetite or overeating?
Feeling bad about yourself - or that you are a failure or have let yourself or your family down?
Trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television?
Moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed? Or the opposite - being so fidgety or restless that you have been moving around a lot more than usual?
Thoughts that you would be better off dead, or of hurting yourself in some way?
### Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by any of the following problems?
Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge
Not being able to stop or control worrying
Worrying too much about different things
Trouble relaxing
Being so restless that it's hard to sit still
Becoming easily annoyed or irritable
Feeling afraid as if something awful might happen
### Over the **last 2 weeks**, how often have you been bothered by any of the following problems?
Over the **last two weeks**, how many days has your work or studying being affected by your asthma?
In the **last six months**  how many times have you visited your GP for non-asthma related problems?
fields.help_text:
Enter a whole number (e.g. 3)

For example, if you visited the Dr because you needed a diabetes checkup this would score "1".

fields.text: How helpful for your asthma do you find the medicines which you doctor has given you?
I take my oral steroids daily at the full recommended dose.
I take my inhaled steroids daily at the fully recommended dose

Would you like us to demonstrate the SignalBox system by sending you an SMS message and making a brief automated call to your mobile phone?
This instruction and the date question below are part of an 'instrument' which can be repeated on multiple pages, without having to re-type the same question multiple times.
A slider to choose a number
A slider to choose a range
For how many years have you had asthma?
Which types of inhaler have you been prescribed?
Blue or grey inhaler?
Brown inhaler?
Any other colour of inhaler?
If you take medication for your asthma other than inhalers (e.g. pills or injections), please describe them here:
When you feel better, do you sometimes stop taking your medication?
Sometimes if you feel worse when you take the medication, do you stop taking it?
When you feel better, do you sometimes stop taking your medication?=
### Here are some problems that can be caused by NOT taking asthma medication

> You get a cold and become very wheezy, keeping you in bed for several days.

If this happened to you, how bad would it be on a scale from 0 to 100:

> You find yourself short of breath, and find it hard to climb a flight of stairs at work.

If this happened to you, how bad would it be on a scale from 0 to 100:

> Your asthma keeps you awake because you are coughing and short of breath.

If this happened to you, how bad would it be on a scale from 0 to 100:

> You have an asthma attack and end up in Accident and Emergency. You have to stay in hospital overnight, until your breathing improves.

If this happened to you, how bad would it be on a scale from 0 to 100:
### Imagine that the following problems had been caused by taking asthma medications as directed:

> Your voice becomes hoarse and it can be sore when talking.

If this happened to you, how bad would it be on a scale from 0 to 100:

> Your bones become weaker (a condition called osteoporosis) and you have to take calcium supplements

If this happened to you, how bad would it be on a scale from 0 to 100:

> Your bones become weaker, and you suffer a broken wrist.

If this happened to you, how bad would it be on a scale from 0 to 100:

> You develop oral thrush (a yeast infection in the mouth) which gives you an unpleasant taste, soreness, a burning sensation on the tongue and difficulty swallowing? <!-- symptoms taken from http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Oral-thrush---adults/Pages/Introduction.aspx -->

If this happened to you, how bad would it be on a scale from 0 to 100:

> Your face become quite puffy and rounded, and this is noticeable to your friends and family.

If this happened to you, how bad would it be on a scale from 0 to 100:

> Your skin becomes delicate. You find it is easy to cut or bruise yourself, and patches of skin become sore at times.

If this happened to you, how bad would it be on a scale from 0 to 100:

> Your appetite increases and you gain weight — 2 stones or 12kg - over the course of 6 months.

If this happened to you, how bad would it be on a scale from 0 to 100:

### How **likely** are the conseuqences of asthma, and the side effects of asthma medications described above?

We'd like you to indicate how likely each of the situations described are **to happen to you**.

The slider below allows you to select a range indicating how **likely** each thing is to happen. For example:


- Selecting a range of 80 to 90 would mean you are between 80% and 90% sure it will happen — that is, you are *quite certain* that it is *very likely* to happen.

- Selecting a range of 10% to 90% would mean you think it *might happen*, but are *very unsure* about the chances.

- Selecting a range of 0% to 40% means you think it is *quite unlikely* to happen, but you can't be completely certain.


How likely is it that these things **will happen to you**?
### Here are some problems that can be caused by NOT taking asthma medication. How likely are they?

> You get a cold and become very wheezy, keeping you in bed for several days.

How likely is this to happen? Use the slider to select a range which expresses how sure you are about this:

> You find yourself short of breath, and find it hard to climb a flight of stairs at work.

How likely is this to happen? Use the slider to select a range which expresses how sure you are about this:

> Your asthma keeps you awake because you are coughing and short of breath.

How likely is this to happen? Use the slider to select a range which expresses how sure you are about this:

> You have an asthma attack and end up in Accident and Emergency. You have to stay in hospital overnight, until your breathing improves.

How likely is this to happen? Use the slider to select a range which expresses how sure you are about this:
### How likely do you think it is that the following problems could be caused by taking asthma medications as directed:

> Your voice becomes hoarse and it can be sore when talking.

How likely is this to happen? Use the slider to select a range which expresses how sure you are about this:

> Your bones become weaker (a condition called osteoporosis) and you have to take calcium supplements

How likely is this to happen? Use the slider to select a range which expresses how sure you are about this:

> Your bones become weaker, and you suffer a broken wrist.

How likely is this to happen? Use the slider to select a range which expresses how sure you are about this:

> You develop oral thrush (a yeast infection in the mouth) which gives you an unpleasant taste, soreness, a burning sensation on the tongue and difficulty swallowing? <!-- symptoms taken from http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Oral-thrush---adults/Pages/Introduction.aspx -->

How likely is this to happen? Use the slider to select a range which expresses how sure you are about this:

> Your face become quite puffy and rounded, and this is noticeable to your friends and family.

How likely is this to happen? Use the slider to select a range which expresses how sure you are about this:

> Your skin becomes delicate. You find it is easy to cut or bruise yourself, and patches of skin become sore at times.

How likely is this to happen? Use the slider to select a range which expresses how sure you are about this:

> Your appetite increases and you gain weight — 2 stones or 12kg - over the course of 6 months.

# Asthma control test
During the past 4 weeks, how often did your asthma prevent you from getting as much done at work, school or home?
During the past 4 weeks, how often have you had shortness of breath?
During the past 4 weeks, how often have you used your reliever inhaler (usually blue)?
How would you rate your asthma control during the past 4 weeks?

# Other health problems.

In the last month have you experienced any of the following symptoms?
Heartburn
Constipation
Diarrhoea
Back pain
Painful joints
Feeling tired for no reason
Headache or migraine

# Mood

Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by any of the following problems?
Little interest or pleasure in doing things?
Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless?
Trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much?
Feeling tired or having little energy?
Poor appetite or overeating?
Feeling bad about yourself - or that you are a failure or have let yourself or your family down?
Trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television?
Moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed? Or the opposite - being so fidgety or restless that you have been moving around a lot more than usual?
Thoughts that you would be better off dead, or of hurting yourself in some way?

# Mood 2

Over the last 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by any of the following problems?
Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge
Not being able to stop or control worrying
Worrying too much about different things
Trouble relaxing
Being so restless that it's hard to sit still
Becoming easily annoyed or irritable
Feeling afraid as if something awful might  happen

# What do you expect from the difficult asthma clinic?

The following questions ask about what you think the difficult asthma clinic can do for you.
Do you believe that the difficult asthma clinic will help you?
How much do you want you asthma to improve?
Approximately how many times have you been to the difficult asthma clinic before?
# Additional questions about your previous visits
I enjoy coming to the difficult asthma clinic
I have learned new things about myself by coming to the difficult asthma clinic
I find the difficult asthma clinic interesting
Since coming to the difficult asthma clinic I put more effort into managing my asthma
